case: A 78-year-old Black with a history of atrial fibrillation, not on anticoagulation therapy, and remote history of abdominal surgery presents to the emergency department with severe, acute-onset, generalized abdominal pain, tachycardia, hypotension, and tachypnea.
differential: Acute mesenteric ischemia (embolism or thrombosis, especially due to atrial fibrillation and no anticoagulation)
Bowel perforation (possibly related to remote abdominal surgery and risk of adhesions)
Acute perforated peptic ulcer
Ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm
Acute pancreatitis
Sepsis secondary to intra-abdominal infection (e.g., peritonitis, diverticulitis with perforation)
Small bowel obstruction with ischemia (due to adhesions from prior surgery)
Acute myocardial infarction with referred abdominal pain
Volvulus (especially sigmoid, given age)
Acute cholecystitis with perforation

Acute bowel obstruction (adhesions from prior surgery as a risk factor)
Ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm
Acute pancreatitis

Sepsis of intra-abdominal origin
Acute myocardial infarction (atypical presentation with abdominal pain)
Peptic ulcer perforation
Volvulus
